text: Avoid a cure that is worse than the disease.
author: Aesop

text: Don't believe everything you hear.
author: Aesop

text: Save for a rainy day.
author: Aesop

text: Yield to all and you will soon have nothing to yield.
author: Aesop

text: Fine feathers don't make fine birds.
author: Aesop

text: Liars often set their own traps.
author: Aesop

text: One who steals has no right to complain if he is robbed.
author: Aesop

text: It is easy to be brave from a distance.
author: Aesop

text: Each person has his strong point.
author: Aesop

text: It is foolish to try to imitate the skills of others.
author: Aesop

text: It pays to be prepared.
author: Aesop

text: It is possible to have too much of a good thing.
author: Aesop

text: Little friends may prove great friends.
author: Aesop

text: Misfortune tests the sincerity of friends.
author: Aesop

text: No act of kindness no matter how small is ever wasted.
author: Aesop

text: One good turn deserves another.
author: Aesop

text: Please all and you will soon please none.
author: Aesop

text: If you can't say anything nice, then don't say anything at all.
author: Aesop

text: Don't kill the goose that lays the golden egg.
author: Aesop

text: Gratitude is the sign of noble souls.
author: Aesop

text: He that is hard to please, may get nothing in the end.
author: Aesop

text: It pays to be content with your lot.
author: Aesop

text: Don't pretend to be something you aren't.
author: Aesop

text: Honesty is the best policy.
author: Aesop

text: You can fool people some of the time, but you can't fool them all of the time.
author: Aesop

text: A crust in comfort is better than a feast in fear.
author: Aesop

text: All of us, the great and the little have need of each other.
author: Aesop

text: Vices are their own punishment.
author: Aesop

text: Good things come in small packages.
author: Aesop

text: False friends leave you in times of trouble.
author: Aesop

text: He who laughs last, laughs best.
author: Aesop

text: Example is the best precept.
author: Aesop

text: Kindness is more persuasive than force.
author: Aesop

text: Little by little does the trick.
author: Aesop

text: Slow and steady wins the race.
author: Aesop

text: Happy is the person who learns from the misfortunes of others.
author: Aesop

text: Easier said than done.
author: Aesop

text: In a crisis, give help first and then advice.
author: Aesop

text: It is useless attacking the insensible.
author: Aesop

text: He who plots to hurt others often hurts himself.
author: Aesop

text: Persuasion is better than force.
author: Aesop

text: It is easy to kick a person when he is down.
author: Aesop

text: Outside show is a poor substitute for inner worth.
author: Aesop

text: Don't go looking for trouble.
author: Aesop

text: United we stand; divided we fall.
author: Aesop

text: Give assistance not advice in a crisis.
author: Aesop

text: Implementation beats oration.
author: Aesop

text: You can't play all the time.
author: Aesop

text: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted.
author: Aesop

text: In union there is strength.
author: Aesop

text: After the rain cometh the fair weather.
author: Aesop

text: Any excuse will serve a tyrant.
author: Aesop

text: United we stand, divided we fall.
author: Aesop

text: Beware lest you lose the substance by grasping at the shadow.
author: Aesop

text: The smaller the mind the greater the conceit.
author: Aesop

text: Whoever neglects old friends for the sake of new deserves what he gets if he loses both.
author: Aesop

text: Our insignificance is often the cause of our safety.
author: Aesop

text: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted
author: Aesop

text: Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
author: Aesop

text: Enemies promises were made to be broken.
author: Aesop

text: We often give our enemies the means for our own destruction.
author: Aesop

text: Better to starve free than be a fat slave.
author: Aesop

text: We would often be sorry if our wishes were granted.
author: Aesop

text: We hang the petty thieves and appoint the great ones to public office.
author: Aesop

text: Union gives strength.
author: Aesop

text: Don't count your chickens before they are hatched.
author: Aesop

text: Enemies' promises were made to be broken.
author: Aesop

text: Adventure is worthwhile.
author: Aesop

text: Better to starve free than be a fat slave
author: Aesop

text: We should use our judgment before coming to a decision.
author: Aesop

text: Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.
author: Aesop

text: The injuries we do and the injuries we suffer are seldom weighed on the same scales.
author: Aesop

text: People often grudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
author: Aesop

text: Slow but steady wins the race.
author: Aesop

text: Don't let your special character and values, the secret that you know and no one else does, the truth, don't let that get swallowed up by the great chewing complacency.
author: Aesop

text: Evil companions bring more hurt than profit.
author: Aesop

text: It is thrifty to prepare today for the wants of tomorrow.
author: Aesop

text: Destroy the seed of evil, or it will grow up to your ruin.
author: Aesop

text: Every truth has two sides; it is as well to look at both, before we commit ourselves to either.
author: Aesop

text: Appearances are deceiving.
author: Aesop

text: Men often applaud an imitation and hiss the real thing.
author: Aesop

text: A false tale often betrays itself.
author: Aesop

text: Every tale is not to be believed.
author: Aesop

text: The cat always leaves a mark on his friend.
author: Aesop

text: Obscurity brings safety.
author: Aesop

text: Acquaintance softens prejudice.
author: Aesop

text: Better beans and bacon in peace than cakes and ale in fear.
author: Aesop

text: The little reed, bending to the force of the wind, soon stood upright again when the storm had passed over.
author: Aesop

text: Betray a friend and youâ€™ll often find you have ruined yourself.
author: Aesop

text: It is not only fine feathers that make fine birds.
author: Aesop

text: Conceit may bring about one's own downfall.
author: Aesop

text: If you had half as much brains as you have beard, you would have looked before you leaped.
author: Aesop

text: The haft of the arrow had been feathered with one of the eagle's own plumes. We often give our enemies the means of our own destruction.
author: Aesop

text: The greatest kindness will not bind the ungrateful.
author: Aesop

text: A doubtful friend is worse than a certain enemy. Let a man be one thing or the other, and we then know how to meet him.
author: Aesop

text: The haft of the arrow had been feathered with one of the eagles own plumes. We often give our enemies the means of our own destruction.
author: Aesop

text: Betray a friend and you'll often find you have ruined yourself.
author: Aesop

text: The unhappy derive comfort from the misfortunes of others.
author: Aesop
